text: today is a sad day one of the most
widely used and best neovim plugins has
announced that it will be archived on
August the 11th 2023 that is exactly one
month away from the time of recording
that plugin is null LS null LS is a
special kind of plugin in the neovim
ecosystem
this plugin is so useful that it's used
by the major neovin based configurations
such as Astro lazy vim and lunavim
although it's not used by NV chat
if you've been following along with my
perfect neovim setup series then you'll
know we use null LS in our
configurations however I'm sure there's
a few of you watching that don't know
what it does so what is null LS
well in short null LS provided LSP
bindings to a number of software tooling
that did not have native LSP support
a large number of Tooling in fact just
short of 300 unique sources as they're
called in null or less
these tools range across a number of
different categories one of which being
formatters so that you're able to Auto
format your code whenever you save your
project or linters allowing you to see
inline static analysis from within
neovim
another one of my favorite features was
code actions for things such as git
signs which allows you to bring up a
menu of all the possible actions you can
take on your chosen line
such as figuring out who originally
wrote that questionable Lana code using
get blame which ends up usually being
myself now a lot of these tools will
actually work without nonetheless mvchat
itself has custom mappings for these get
sign actions and a number of LSP servers
have linters within them already but not
every tool is covered and the real power
of null LS was the ease of use the
standardization and the sheer number of
sources it's supported which is why
those heavier near Vim based
configurations we mentioned earlier
pretty much just rap null LS under the
hood
having a single interface to manage all
of these sources was really powerful for
configuration but that's likely part of
the problem in the first place
so what happened why is null LS being
archived well the author Jose Alvarez
gave a detailed message on issue 1621
where he shared most of his thoughts in
his post he says he struggled to find
the time and energy to continue
maintaining the null LS package
especially as he no longer uses near
them as his primary editor I can
understand how that would be difficult
if I was maintaining an emacs or a
Sublime Text plugin and not even using
the editor in my day-to-day well yeah
that would suck
Jose also mentions in his post that null
LS is highly exposed to any of them
changes which do come often this means
that there's a lot of work that needs to
go in to keep it up to date and due to
the sheer size of the code base both the
core plug-in and the 300 or so supported
sources it's a grueling and thankless
task to keep supporting
Jose did try to reach out to some of the
providers of other sources but it was
kind of futile
ultimately Jose believes that a total
rewrite may be justified in order to
take null is to its true potential
especially with the Learned knowledge of
how popular the built-in sources are
if you want to know more of Jose's
thoughts I recommend reading the post
after this video
beforehand though I just want to talk
about the future
so what's next well there's a few ways
to answer that question but I'm gonna
focus on three different timelines
short-term medium term and long term
for the short term a suitable
replacement probably needs to be found
the EFM language server looks to be a
viable option and it's something I want
to play around with a little more
it appears to be more decentralized and
only focuses on the core language server
implementation
and others are providing the sources
which could possibly solve one of the
core problems Jose mentioned in his post
here's another repo I found which has a
large number of sources already
configured but it's discrete from the
main EFM LS repo
I'll likely do a deeper dive on efmls in
the near future after having played with
it some more
I'm also really Keen to see what the
major neovim configurations end up going
with as well especially as this is going
to be a large migration for them over
the next month or so as for my own
channel well moving forward I'll be
using whichever plugin takes null ls's
place
I've thought about reshooting some of
the videos I've already done but this
would probably be quite tedious and it
doesn't solve the core underlying
problem this does lead me on to my
medium term point however for the medium
term well I've Got Something Brewing
over the next few months to potentially
help mitigate against these sort of big
package changes when it comes to my
videos and the series this might just
give me a bit of a boost in order to
actually sit down and work on it but
there's a couple of other things that
need to happen beforehand which is all I
can really say at this point
for the long term does this mean that
neovim is dead or at least has a
long-term issue well no not really any
of them will be fine and a new package
Will Rise From the Ashes of nalai less
as it always does this isn't the first
time that something like this has
happened and it certainly won't be the
last it does bring up the same issues as
I mentioned in my video on gorilla mux
however when it comes to open source but
there's also a trend in software
development at the moment that I think
is concerning but I have another video
on that coming out in the near future
when it comes to open source who knows
what a better solution looks like maybe
the system we have is the best it'll be
but maintainers really need more than
just thanks for the work they put in
especially when they enable productivity
within huge companies I don't know what
a solution looks like right now but if
you have one well I'd love to hear about
it in the comments either way a big
thank you to Jose for what he's done and
I hope you can enjoy a well-earned break
a big thank you and shout out to my
newest Channel member FaZe Anza and
thank you to everybody else for watching
this video was a little different from
the normal ones I do but uh let me know
if you enjoyed it other than that I'll
see you on the next one
